title: Martin Luther
shortDescription: Initiator of the Protestant Reformation; theologian, professor, and reformer
biography: German theologian, professor, and reformer who initiated the Protestant Reformation. Posted the Ninety-Five Theses in 1517, challenging indulgences and papal authority. Excommunicated in 1521, he translated the Bible into German and established the theological foundations of Lutheranism. Central hub of the Reformation network with connections to virtually all other reformers.

title: John Calvin
shortDescription: Systematizer of Reformed theology and leader of the Genevan Reformation
biography: French theologian, pastor, and reformer who systematized Reformed Protestant theology. His Institutes of the Christian Religion became the definitive Reformed theological work. Led Geneva's reformation from 1541, establishing church discipline and the Geneva Academy. His influence shaped Reformed churches worldwide.

title: Huldrych Zwingli
shortDescription: Founder of Swiss Reformed tradition; led Zurich Reformation
biography: Swiss priest and theologian who founded the Swiss Reformed tradition independently of Luther. Led the Zurich Reformation from 1519, developing a distinctive symbolic understanding of the Eucharist. Died in the Battle of Kappel defending Protestant cantons against Catholic forces.

title: Erasmus of Rotterdam
shortDescription: Prince of Humanists; published Greek New Testament enabling vernacular translations
biography: Dutch humanist scholar, theologian, and satirist known as the 'Prince of Humanists.' His Greek New Testament (1516) enabled Protestant vernacular translations. Remained Catholic but laid intellectual groundwork for reform through biblical scholarship and critique of church abuses. Broke with Luther over free will controversy.

title: William Tyndale
shortDescription: First to print English New Testament from Greek; shaped English biblical language
biography: English scholar and translator who produced the first printed English New Testament from Greek (1526). Approximately 80% of his wording appears in the King James Bible. Worked in exile in Antwerp and was executed as a heretic at Vilvoorde in 1536.

title: Thomas Cranmer
shortDescription: Archbishop of Canterbury; architect of English Reformation liturgy
biography: Archbishop of Canterbury who shaped the English Reformation's liturgy and doctrine. Created the Book of Common Prayer (1549, 1552) and the Forty-Two Articles. Annulled Henry VIII's marriage to Catherine of Aragon. Executed as a heretic under Mary I, becoming one of the Oxford Martyrs.

title: Philip Melanchthon
shortDescription: Luther's chief collaborator; author of Augsburg Confession; 'Preceptor of Germany'
biography: German humanist scholar and theologian who was Luther's closest collaborator. Systematized Lutheran theology in Loci Communes and authored the Augsburg Confession. Known as the 'Preceptor of Germany' for his educational reforms. Attempted to bridge Lutheran and Reformed traditions.

title: Johannes Bugenhagen
shortDescription: Luther's pastor and confessor; organized Lutheran churches across northern Germany
biography: German pastor and theologian who served as Luther's pastor and confessor. Married Luther and Katharina von Bora, baptized their children, and preached Luther's funeral sermon. Drafted church orders for many territories including Denmark, organizing the institutional structure of Lutheranism.

title: Justus Jonas
shortDescription: Translator of Luther's works; present at Luther's death
biography: German theologian and translator who translated Luther's and Melanchthon's Latin works into German, making them accessible to laypeople. Participated in the Marburg Colloquy and Diet of Augsburg. Present at Luther's death in Eisleben in 1546.

title: Caspar Cruciger the Elder
shortDescription: Wittenberg theologian; collaborated on Luther's Bible translation
biography: German theologian and professor at Wittenberg who collaborated with Luther on the Bible translation and assisted with theological disputations.

title: Georg Spalatin
shortDescription: Secretary to Frederick the Wise; crucial intermediary protecting Luther
biography: German humanist who served as secretary and chaplain to Elector Frederick the Wise. Crucial intermediary between Luther and the elector, explaining Luther's theology and helping secure his protection. His behind-the-scenes work was essential to Luther's survival.

title: Andreas Karlstadt
shortDescription: Early Luther ally turned radical reformer; pioneer of iconoclasm
biography: German theologian who was an early Luther ally but led radical reforms during Luther's Wartburg exile, including iconoclasm and a symbolic view of the Eucharist. Eventually expelled from Saxony, he later allied with Swiss Reformed circles.

title: Katharina von Bora
shortDescription: Former nun; Luther's wife and model for Protestant marriage
biography: Former Cistercian nun who escaped her convent in 1523 and married Martin Luther in 1525. Became the model for Protestant clerical marriage and family life. Managed their household, farm, and brewery, enabling Luther's work.

title: Lucas Cranach the Elder
shortDescription: Court painter who created the visual imagery of the Reformation
biography: German painter and printmaker who served as court painter to Frederick the Wise. Created the defining visual imagery of the Reformation through portraits of Luther and other reformers, woodcuts, and altarpieces. Close friend of Luther and burgomaster of Wittenberg.

title: Johann Agricola
shortDescription: Early Lutheran theologian; involved in Antinomian controversy
biography: German theologian and early follower of Luther who became involved in the Antinomian controversy over the role of the law in Christian life. Later served as court preacher in Brandenburg.

title: Thomas Müntzer
shortDescription: Radical reformer and leader in the German Peasants' War
biography: German radical reformer who emerged from Lutheran circles but emphasized direct revelation over Scripture. Led peasant forces in the German Peasants' War and was executed after the Battle of Frankenhausen. Influenced later radical movements though he was not himself an Anabaptist.

title: Heinrich Bullinger
shortDescription: Successor to Zwingli; led Zurich church for 44 years; vast correspondence network
biography: Swiss reformer who succeeded Zwingli as Antistes of Zurich after the Battle of Kappel (1531). Led the Zurich church for 44 years and authored the First and Second Helvetic Confessions. His vast correspondence network (approximately 12,000 letters) influenced Reformed churches across Europe.

title: Leo Jud
shortDescription: Zwingli's close collaborator in Zurich; Bible translator
biography: Swiss reformer who was Zwingli's close friend from their student days under Thomas Wyttenbach at Basel. Served as pastor at St. Peter's in Zurich and collaborated on Bible translation and liturgical reform.

title: Johannes Oecolampadius
shortDescription: Leader of the Basel Reformation; Zwingli's ally on the Eucharist
biography: German-Swiss theologian who led the Basel Reformation. Allied with Zwingli on the symbolic understanding of the Eucharist and participated in the Marburg Colloquy. Died shortly after Zwingli in 1531.

title: Rudolf Gwalther
shortDescription: Zwingli's son-in-law; succeeded Bullinger as Antistes of Zurich
biography: Swiss reformer who married Zwingli's daughter Regula. Succeeded Bullinger as Antistes of Zurich in 1575, continuing the Zwinglian Reformed tradition.

title: Kaspar Megander
shortDescription: Defender of Zwinglian sacramental views
biography: Swiss reformer who defended Zwinglian sacramental views against Lutheran influence and was involved in Bern's Reformation.

title: Guillaume Farel
shortDescription: Fiery preacher who recruited Calvin to Geneva
biography: French-Swiss reformer and itinerant preacher who introduced the Reformation to French-speaking Switzerland. Famously persuaded Calvin to stay in Geneva in 1536, threatening God's judgment if he left. Known for his passionate, confrontational temperament.

title: Pierre Viret
shortDescription: Reformed Lausanne with Farel; known for gentle pastoral approach
biography: Swiss reformer who worked with Farel to reform Lausanne and Geneva. Known for a more gentle, pastoral temperament than Calvin or Farel. Part of the 'triumvirate' that led the French-speaking Swiss Reformation.

title: Theodore Beza
shortDescription: Calvin's successor in Geneva; first rector of Geneva Academy
biography: French-Swiss theologian who became Calvin's closest associate and successor. First rector of the Geneva Academy (1559) and chief pastor of Geneva after Calvin's death (1564). Developed Reformed orthodoxy through his theological writings and leadership.

title: Pierre Robert Olivétan
shortDescription: Calvin's cousin; produced first French Bible from original languages
biography: French reformer and Bible translator who was Calvin's cousin. Produced the first French Bible translated from the original Hebrew and Greek (1535), commissioned by the Waldensians. Calvin wrote the Latin preface. May have influenced Calvin's interest in reform.

title: Martin Bucer
shortDescription: Strasbourg reformer and mediator; mentored Calvin; influenced Cranmer
biography: German reformer who led the Strasbourg Reformation alongside Capito. Key mediating figure who attempted to reconcile Lutheran and Reformed positions. Mentored Calvin during his Strasbourg exile (1538-1541) and later influenced Cranmer's Prayer Book in England.

title: Wolfgang Capito
shortDescription: Co-leader of Strasbourg Reformation with Bucer
biography: German theologian who co-led the Strasbourg Reformation with Bucer. Co-authored the Tetrapolitan Confession and was initially tolerant of Anabaptists. Met Erasmus and Zwingli at Basel.

title: Katharina Schütz Zell
shortDescription: One of few prominent women in magisterial Reformation; reformer and writer
biography: German reformer who married priest Matthew Zell in 1523, one of the first clerical marriages in Strasbourg. An active reformer in her own right, she wrote theological works, defended clerical marriage, and cared for religious refugees.

title: Matthew Zell
shortDescription: Early Strasbourg reformer; one of first priests to marry
biography: German priest and early Strasbourg reformer who was among the first to marry openly, challenging clerical celibacy. Welcomed religious refugees to Strasbourg.

title: Thomas Cromwell
shortDescription: Architect of English Reformation's legal structure; dissolved monasteries
biography: English statesman and chief minister to Henry VIII who engineered the legal and administrative structure of the English Reformation. Dissolved the monasteries, promoted the vernacular Bible, and patronized reformers. Executed in 1540.

title: Hugh Latimer
shortDescription: Bishop of Worcester; powerful preacher; Oxford Martyr
biography: English bishop and reformer known for his powerful evangelical preaching. Bishop of Worcester under Henry VIII and prominent preacher under Edward VI. Burned at the stake with Ridley in Oxford in 1555, one of the Oxford Martyrs.

title: Nicholas Ridley
shortDescription: Bishop of London; shaped Protestant liturgy; Oxford Martyr
biography: English bishop and theologian who served as Cranmer's chaplain and collaborated on liturgical reform. As Bishop of London, he replaced stone altars with communion tables. Burned at the stake with Latimer in Oxford in 1555.

title: Miles Coverdale
shortDescription: Produced first complete printed English Bible
biography: English Bible translator who produced the first complete printed English Bible (1535) using Tyndale's work where available and translating the rest from German and Latin. Supervised the Great Bible (1539) and briefly served as Bishop of Exeter.

title: John Foxe
shortDescription: Author of Book of Martyrs; shaped English Protestant identity
biography: English historian and martyrologist whose Actes and Monuments (Book of Martyrs, 1563) documented Protestant martyrs and shaped English Protestant identity and anti-Catholic sentiment for centuries.

title: Thomas Bilney
shortDescription: Cambridge reformer who converted Latimer; early English Protestant martyr
biography: English priest and reformer who was converted by reading Erasmus's Greek New Testament. Converted Hugh Latimer to evangelical views at Cambridge. Burned at Norwich in 1531, one of the first prominent English Protestant martyrs.

title: Robert Barnes
shortDescription: Cambridge reformer; friend of Luther; diplomatic intermediary
biography: English theologian who was part of the Cambridge reform group and became friends with Luther in Wittenberg. Served as diplomatic intermediary between England and Lutheran Germany. Burned at Smithfield in 1540, the same day Thomas Cromwell was executed.

title: John Frith
shortDescription: Young theologian; Tyndale's associate; burned at 30
biography: English theologian who assisted Tyndale in exile and wrote against purgatory and transubstantiation. Burned at Smithfield in 1533 at only 30 years old.

title: John Hooper
shortDescription: Zurich-influenced bishop; more radical than Cranmer; martyr
biography: English bishop influenced by Bullinger during his Zurich exile. Bishop of Gloucester and Worcester; more radically Protestant than Cranmer, resisting vestments in the Vestments Controversy. Burned at Gloucester in 1555.

title: Matthew Parker
shortDescription: First Elizabethan Archbishop of Canterbury; consolidated English Reformation
biography: Archbishop of Canterbury under Elizabeth I who consolidated the moderate English Reformation settlement. Oversaw the Bishops' Bible and was part of the Cambridge White Horse group in his youth.

title: Johannes Reuchlin
shortDescription: Foremost German Hebraist; great-uncle of Melanchthon
biography: German humanist scholar and foremost German Hebraist who defended Jewish books against destruction in the Reuchlin Affair. Great-uncle of Melanchthon, whom he encouraged and gave the surname 'Melanchthon.'

title: John Colet
shortDescription: Dean of St. Paul's; encouraged Erasmus's biblical scholarship
biography: English humanist and churchman who founded St. Paul's School and encouraged Erasmus's biblical scholarship. His lectures on Paul at Oxford inspired Erasmus. Died before the Reformation proper.

title: Thomas More
shortDescription: Humanist and Lord Chancellor; executed for opposing Henry VIII; Catholic martyr
biography: English statesman, humanist, and close friend of Erasmus who opposed the Reformation. As Lord Chancellor, wrote polemics against Tyndale and Luther. Executed for refusing to accept Henry VIII as head of the church; Catholic martyr and saint.

title: Jacques Lefèvre d'Étaples
shortDescription: Pioneer of French biblical humanism; produced French New Testament
biography: French humanist scholar and pioneer of French biblical humanism. Produced a French New Testament translation (1530) and influenced early French reformers including Farel. Remained within the Catholic Church while advocating evangelical reform.

title: Guillaume Briçonnet
shortDescription: Bishop of Meaux; patron of early French evangelical reform
biography: French bishop who led the reform-minded Meaux Circle in the early 1520s. Patron of Lefèvre d'Étaples and early French evangelicals. Attempted reform within the Catholic Church but was pressured to suppress reformers after 1525.

title: Conrad Grebel
shortDescription: Co-founder of Swiss Brethren (Anabaptists); performed first adult rebaptism
biography: Swiss radical reformer who co-founded the Swiss Brethren (Anabaptists), breaking with Zwingli over infant baptism. Performed the first adult rebaptism on January 21, 1525. Died of plague in exile.

title: Felix Manz
shortDescription: Co-founder of Swiss Brethren; first Swiss Anabaptist executed
biography: Swiss radical reformer who co-founded the Swiss Brethren with Grebel. First Swiss Anabaptist executed, drowned in the Limmat River by Zurich authorities on January 5, 1527—a grim pun on rebaptism.

title: George Blaurock
shortDescription: One of first Anabaptists; missionary to Tyrol; burned at stake
biography: Swiss Anabaptist leader who was baptized by Grebel at the founding of the Swiss Brethren (January 21, 1525). Became a missionary spreading Anabaptism to Tyrol where he was burned at the stake.

title: Balthasar Hubmaier
shortDescription: Most theologically trained Anabaptist leader; burned at stake
biography: German-Moravian Anabaptist theologian who was the most theologically trained Anabaptist leader. Led an Anabaptist community in Nikolsburg, Moravia. Burned at the stake in Vienna.

title: Menno Simons
shortDescription: Leader of peaceful Dutch Anabaptism; Mennonites named after him
biography: Dutch Anabaptist leader who reorganized scattered Dutch Anabaptists after the Münster catastrophe (1534-35). Emphasized nonresistance and discipleship. The Mennonite movement is named after him.

title: Michael Sattler
shortDescription: Author of Schleitheim Confession; foundational Anabaptist statement
biography: South German Anabaptist leader and former Benedictine prior. Author of the Schleitheim Confession (1527), the foundational Anabaptist statement on baptism, ban, Lord's Supper, separation, and nonresistance. Brutally executed at Rottenburg.

title: Marguerite of Navarre
shortDescription: Queen of Navarre; patron and protector of French reformers
biography: Queen of Navarre and sister of King Francis I of France. Used her influence to protect early French reformers including Lefèvre d'Étaples and Clément Marot. Never formally broke with Catholicism but was sympathetic to reform. Author of the Heptameron.

title: Clément Marot
shortDescription: Court poet; French metrical Psalms became foundation of Huguenot worship
biography: French court poet whose metrical translations of Psalms into French verse became the foundation of Huguenot worship. Protected by Marguerite of Navarre when his Protestant sympathies brought danger.

title: Antoine Froment
shortDescription: Early Geneva reformer alongside Farel
biography: French-Swiss reformer who worked alongside Farel in introducing the Reformation to Geneva in the early 1530s. His influence waned after Calvin's rise.

title: Marie Dentière
shortDescription: Former abbess; one of few female Reformation theologians
biography: Former abbess who became one of the few female Reformation theologians. Married Antoine Froment and advocated for women's roles in the church through her theological writings.

title: Frederick the Wise
shortDescription: Elector of Saxony who protected Luther from papal and imperial action
biography: Elector of Saxony who protected Luther from papal and imperial action despite never formally converting. Founded the University of Wittenberg and arranged Luther's 'kidnapping' to Wartburg Castle for his safety after the Diet of Worms.

title: John the Steadfast
shortDescription: Frederick's brother; first openly Lutheran elector
biography: Elector of Saxony who succeeded his brother Frederick the Wise in 1525 and openly embraced Lutheranism. Co-founded the Schmalkaldic League for Protestant defense.

title: John Frederick I
shortDescription: Led Schmalkaldic League; captured after defeat at Mühlberg
biography: Elector of Saxony who succeeded his father John the Steadfast in 1532. Led the Schmalkaldic League in the Schmalkaldic War (1546-47) but was captured after defeat at the Battle of Mühlberg and lost the electorate.

title: Philip of Hesse
shortDescription: Most active Protestant prince; founded University of Marburg; organized Marburg Colloquy
biography: Landgrave of Hesse and one of the most active Protestant princes. Founded the University of Marburg (first Protestant university) and co-founded the Schmalkaldic League. Organized the Marburg Colloquy (1529) to unite Luther and Zwingli. His bigamy scandal (1540) weakened his position.

title: Henry VIII
shortDescription: King of England; broke with Rome over divorce; complex religious position
biography: King of England who broke with Rome over his divorce from Catherine of Aragon, establishing royal supremacy over the English church. His religious position was complex—Catholic in doctrine but Protestant in church structure. Dissolved the monasteries.

title: Charles V
shortDescription: Holy Roman Emperor; chief political opponent of Reformation
biography: Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain who was the chief political opponent of the Protestant Reformation. Presided over the Diet of Worms where Luther was condemned. Eventually defeated the Schmalkaldic League but exhausted by religious wars, abdicated in 1556.

title: Johann Eck
shortDescription: Luther's chief Catholic opponent; Leipzig Debate; drafted Exsurge Domine
biography: German Catholic theologian and Luther's most persistent opponent. At the Leipzig Debate (1519), maneuvered Luther into admitting sympathy with Hus. Helped draft the papal bull Exsurge Domine condemning Luther and wrote the Confutatio against the Augsburg Confession.

title: Cardinal Thomas Cajetan
shortDescription: Thomist scholar who interrogated Luther at Augsburg
biography: Italian cardinal and Thomist theologian who interrogated Luther at Augsburg (1518) on behalf of the pope, demanding recantation. More moderate than Eck but still required Luther's submission. Contributed to drafting Exsurge Domine.

title: John Knox
shortDescription: Central figure of Scottish Reformation; established Presbyterian Kirk
biography: Scottish reformer who established the Presbyterian Church of Scotland. Profoundly influenced by Calvin during his Geneva exile. Wrote the Scots Confession (1560) and famously confronted Mary Queen of Scots. His First Blast of the Trumpet angered Elizabeth I.

title: George Wishart
shortDescription: Scottish reformer; Knox's mentor; martyred
biography: Scottish reformer and preacher who mentored John Knox. His execution by Cardinal Beaton in 1546 galvanized Scottish Protestantism and was avenged by Beaton's murder. Knox served as his bodyguard in his final year.

title: Patrick Hamilton
shortDescription: Scotland's first Protestant martyr; studied at Marburg
biography: Scottish reformer who studied at the University of Marburg and absorbed Lutheran theology. Scotland's first Protestant martyr, burned at St. Andrews in 1528. His 'Patrick's Places' summarized Protestant doctrine.

title: Ninety-Five Theses
shortDescription: Luther's 1517 document that sparked the Reformation

title: Address to the Christian Nobility of the German Nation
shortDescription: Luther's 1520 call for princes to reform the church

title: On the Babylonian Captivity of the Church
shortDescription: Luther's 1520 attack on the sacramental system

title: On the Freedom of a Christian
shortDescription: Luther's clearest statement of justification by faith alone

title: The Bondage of the Will
shortDescription: Luther's 1525 response to Erasmus on free will

title: On Free Will
shortDescription: Erasmus's 1524 defense of human free will against Luther

title: Institutes of the Christian Religion
shortDescription: Calvin's systematic theology; definitive Reformed work

title: Sixty-Seven Articles
shortDescription: Zwingli's platform for the First Zurich Disputation

title: Commentary on True and False Religion
shortDescription: Zwingli's most comprehensive theological work

title: Loci Communes
shortDescription: First systematic presentation of Lutheran theology

title: The Obedience of a Christian Man
shortDescription: Tyndale's argument for royal supremacy over church

title: Luther's German Bible
shortDescription: Most influential German Bible; established literary German

title: Erasmus's Greek New Testament
shortDescription: First published Greek NT; enabled vernacular translations

title: Tyndale's New Testament
shortDescription: First printed English NT from Greek; shaped KJV

title: Tyndale's Pentateuch
shortDescription: First printed English OT books from Hebrew

title: Coverdale Bible
shortDescription: First complete printed English Bible

title: Great Bible
shortDescription: First officially authorized English Bible

title: Geneva Bible
shortDescription: Produced by Marian exiles; most popular English Bible until KJV

title: Olivétan's French Bible
shortDescription: First French Bible from original languages

title: Zurich Bible
shortDescription: Complete Swiss German Bible

title: Augsburg Confession
shortDescription: Primary confession of Lutheran churches

title: Apology of the Augsburg Confession
shortDescription: Melanchthon's defense and expansion of Augsburg Confession

title: Small Catechism
shortDescription: Luther's instruction for ordinary Christians

title: Large Catechism
shortDescription: Luther's extended catechetical instruction

title: Tetrapolitan Confession
shortDescription: Confession of four South German cities at Augsburg

title: First Helvetic Confession
shortDescription: First common confession of Swiss Reformed churches

title: Second Helvetic Confession
shortDescription: Most widely adopted Reformed confession of 16th century

title: Genevan Catechism
shortDescription: Calvin's catechism for the Genevan church

title: Heidelberg Catechism
shortDescription: Warmly personal Reformed catechism

title: Schleitheim Confession
shortDescription: Foundational Anabaptist statement

title: Scots Confession
shortDescription: Foundational confession of Church of Scotland

title: Thirty-Nine Articles
shortDescription: Doctrinal statement of Church of England

title: Book of Common Prayer (1549)
shortDescription: First vernacular prayer book for Church of England

title: Book of Common Prayer (1552)
shortDescription: Revised prayer book with more Protestant theology

title: Strasbourg Liturgy
shortDescription: Reformed liturgy that influenced Calvin and Cranmer

title: Genevan Psalter
shortDescription: Complete metrical Psalter for Reformed worship

title: Luther's Hymns
alternateNames: Ein feste Burg ist unser Gott
shortDescription: German Protestant hymnody; 'A Mighty Fortress'

title: Actes and Monuments (Book of Martyrs)
shortDescription: Comprehensive martyrology shaping English Protestant identity

title: The Praise of Folly
shortDescription: Erasmus's satirical critique of church corruption

title: Enchiridion
shortDescription: Erasmus's program for lay Christian life

title: First Blast of the Trumpet
shortDescription: Knox's argument against female rulers

title: Erasmus's Correspondence
shortDescription: Over 3,000 letters documenting the humanist network

title: Luther's Correspondence
shortDescription: Thousands of letters documenting Reformation spread

title: Bullinger's Correspondence
shortDescription: ~12,000 letters documenting Reformed network across Europe

title: Wittenberg
shortDescription: Birthplace of the Lutheran Reformation

title: University of Wittenberg
shortDescription: Center of Lutheran theological education

title: Castle Church (Schlosskirche)
shortDescription: Site of Ninety-Five Theses posting; Luther and Melanchthon buried here

title: Worms
shortDescription: Site of Diet of Worms where Luther refused to recant

title: Augsburg
shortDescription: Site of 1518 Luther-Cajetan meeting and 1530 Augsburg Confession

title: Marburg
shortDescription: Site of Marburg Colloquy (1529); first Protestant university

title: University of Marburg
shortDescription: First university founded as Protestant institution

title: Nuremberg
shortDescription: Major imperial free city; early adopter of Reformation

title: Eisleben
shortDescription: Luther's birthplace and death place

title: Wartburg Castle
shortDescription: Where Luther was hidden and translated the New Testament

title: Erfurt
shortDescription: Luther's university education and early monastic life

title: Mühlhausen
shortDescription: Center of Müntzer's radical reformation and Peasants' War

title: Zurich
shortDescription: Center of Swiss Reformation under Zwingli and Bullinger

title: Grossmünster
shortDescription: Zwingli's church; center of Zurich Reformation

title: Geneva
shortDescription: Protestant Rome under Calvin's leadership

title: St. Pierre Cathedral
shortDescription: Calvin's church; center of Genevan Reformed worship

title: Geneva Academy
shortDescription: Training ground for Reformed ministers from across Europe

title: Basel
shortDescription: Humanist and printing center; Erasmus's residence

title: University of Basel
shortDescription: Oldest Swiss university; where Zwingli and Jud studied

title: Bern
shortDescription: Powerful Swiss canton that adopted Reformation (1528)

title: Lausanne
shortDescription: French-speaking Swiss city reformed by Viret and Farel

title: Strasbourg
shortDescription: Mediating center between Lutheran and Reformed traditions

title: London
shortDescription: Political center of English Reformation

title: Canterbury
shortDescription: Seat of Archbishop of Canterbury; head of English church

title: Oxford
shortDescription: Site of Oxford Martyrs' execution

title: University of Oxford
shortDescription: Ancient university with complex Reformation history

title: Cambridge
shortDescription: Where English Reformation began intellectually

title: University of Cambridge
shortDescription: Center of early English Protestant thought

title: White Horse Tavern
shortDescription: Meeting place for Cambridge proto-Protestants

title: Antwerp
shortDescription: Commercial and printing center; Tyndale worked here in exile

title: Vilvoorde
shortDescription: Where Tyndale was executed (1536)

title: Paris
shortDescription: Capital of France; Sorbonne condemned Luther

title: University of Paris (Sorbonne)
shortDescription: Premier Catholic theological faculty; condemned Luther

title: Meaux
shortDescription: Site of Meaux Circle under Bishop Briçonnet

title: Rome
shortDescription: Seat of papacy; center of opposition to Reformation

title: Ingolstadt
shortDescription: Home of Johann Eck, Luther's chief Catholic opponent

title: St. Andrews
shortDescription: Ecclesiastical capital of Scotland; site of early martyrdoms

title: University of St. Andrews
shortDescription: Scotland's first university; center of theological education

title: Edinburgh
shortDescription: Capital of Scotland; Knox's base as minister of St. Giles

title: St. Giles' Cathedral
shortDescription: Knox's church; mother church of Scottish Presbyterianism

title: Kappel am Albis
shortDescription: Battlefield where Zwingli was killed (1531)

title: Schleitheim
shortDescription: Where Schleitheim Confession was adopted (1527)

title: Frankenhausen
shortDescription: Decisive battle of German Peasants' War (1525)

title: Lutheran Territorial Churches
shortDescription: Network of state churches that adopted Lutheran confession

title: Church of England
shortDescription: National Protestant church established by royal supremacy

title: Reformed Church of Zurich
shortDescription: First Reformed church; model for Swiss Reformed organization

title: Genevan Reformed Church
shortDescription: Model for Calvinist church organization worldwide

title: Company of Pastors
shortDescription: Collective body of Geneva's pastors

title: Geneva Consistory
shortDescription: Disciplinary body for Genevan church

title: Church of Scotland (The Kirk)
shortDescription: National Reformed church of Scotland

title: Lutheran Reformation
shortDescription: Initial Protestant movement sparked by Luther

title: Swiss Reformed Movement
shortDescription: Reformed Protestantism originating in Zurich and Geneva

title: Radical Reformation
shortDescription: Movements rejecting both Catholic and magisterial Protestant churches

title: Swiss Brethren
shortDescription: First Anabaptist group

title: Mennonite Movement
shortDescription: Peaceful Anabaptist movement named after Menno Simons

title: Christian Humanism
shortDescription: Intellectual movement emphasizing return to biblical sources

title: English Reformation
shortDescription: Reformation in England driven by political and religious factors

title: Meaux Circle
shortDescription: Early French evangelical reform movement

title: Schmalkaldic League
shortDescription: Military alliance of Lutheran princes and cities

title: Swiss Confederacy
shortDescription: Federation of Swiss cantons divided by Reformation

title: Augustinian Order
shortDescription: Luther's religious order

title: Dominican Order
shortDescription: Order of Tetzel and Cajetan; often Catholic opponents of reform

title: Diet of Worms (1521)
shortDescription: Imperial diet where Luther refused to recant

title: Diet of Augsburg (1530)
shortDescription: Imperial diet where Augsburg Confession was presented

title: Marburg Colloquy
shortDescription: Attempt to unite Lutheran and Zwinglian reformers

title: First Zurich Disputation
shortDescription: Public disputation establishing legal basis for Zurich Reformation

title: Leipzig Debate
shortDescription: Academic debate accelerating Luther's break with Rome

title: Peace of Augsburg
shortDescription: Settlement establishing legal coexistence of Lutheranism and Catholicism

title: Froben Press
shortDescription: Premier humanist publishing house in Basel

title: Wittenberg Printing Network
shortDescription: Network of printers publishing Luther's works

title: Geneva Printing Network
shortDescription: Published Calvin's works and Geneva Bible
